name: Elysium
shortDescription: Paradise within the Underworld where heroes and the righteous enjoy eternal bliss
fullDescription: Elysium (Greek: ·º®ŒªœçœÉŒπŒøŒΩ œÄŒµŒ¥ŒØŒøŒΩ Elysion pedion, 'Elysian Fields') is the paradise region of the Underworld reserved for heroes, the righteous, and those favored by the gods. Unlike the shadowy Asphodel Meadows where ordinary souls dwell, Elysium enjoys perpetual spring, pleasant climate, and freedom from suffering. Souls feast, compete in games, pursue music and poetry, and enjoy eternal peace. According to some accounts, souls who reach Elysium three times through reincarnation move to the Isles of the Blessed. Heroes like Achilles, Heracles (after apotheosis), and Menelaus (as Zeus's son-in-law) were promised Elysium. The realm represents the Greek ideal of eternal reward for excellence (arete) and virtue.

mythologyContexts.symbolism: Elysium symbolizes ultimate reward for virtue, heroism, and divine favor. Represents Greek aspiration for eternal happiness and honor beyond death.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: 'Elysian' entered language meaning blissfully happy or paradisiacal. Influenced later concepts of Heaven and paradise.
